Some of its best friends harbored grave doubts ©bout the course the government had

It was obvious that ©11 was not well within the democratic party coalition, despite the

Cabinet ministers of the Liberal and Social Democratic parties were still completely
loyal to Premier Scelba. But they and their Bepublicen party allies were having fresh doubts
about the loyalty to the coalition government of Scelba,s own Christian Democratic party.
It seemed evident, at one point, that Scelba shared these doubts. In speaking to
Christian Democratic members of the chamber of deputies, the premier pointedly called for a
stricter cooperation between party and government.
But in spite of repeated pledges for such cooperation by the party secretary, Amintore
Fanfani, it was obvious that the Christian Democrats were again suffering from their chronic
ailment, factional differences. The right wing of the party was again charging the govern¬
ment with laxity toward the Communists. Some members of Fanfani #s left-oenter democratic
Initiative” faction were saying that the party secretary was actually dissatisfied with
Signor Scelba and would soon make another bid for the premiership himself.
And as though the internal troubles of Italy#s biggest party were not enou^i, a deep-
seated split in the goveinment-supporting Liberal party came to the surface again, with the
resignation of three left-wing Liberals from the party directorate.
There was not doubt in anyone's mind as to the beneficiary of this uneasiness, uncer¬
tainty and confusion. The beneficiary was the group that can always exploit conditions of
uneasiness, uncertainty and confusion. The beneficiary was the Communist party.
There was striking unanimity among democratic party politicians on one thing* the
belief that the Communists were stronger in Italy this autumn than ever before.
In light of the embarrassing political somersaults they had performed on the deeply-
felt Trieste issue this might seem incredible. But some Italian democrats conceded gloomily
that if new national elections were held now, the Communists and their left Socialist allies
mig&t poll as much as 40 per cent of the total vote, compared with 35 per cent in 1953.
And all its supporters agreed that it would be perilous for the government coalition to
call new elections at this time.
